choices.text:
what is a Hendiadys?
A hendiadys (also known as a compound epithet) is a figure of speech in which two words are combined with a conjunction, typically "and," to create a single descriptive phrase. The purpose of using this technique is often to emphasize or exaggerate certain qualities or characteristics of the object being described. An example of hendiadys can be found in the famous line from William Shakespeare's play Romeo and Juliet: "Juliet, fair devil," which combines two descriptive words with a conjunction to create an emphatic and memorable description of Juliet.
